''Northeast Pacific population''{{cite web|url=http://oldredlist.iucnredlist.org/details/8098/0 |accessdate=January 15, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070310230425/http://oldredlist.iucnredlist.org/details/8098/0 |archivedate=March 10, 2007 }} * [[Southern right whale]]{{cite web|url=http://oldredlist.iucnredlist.org/details/8153/0 |title=Eubalaena australis (Southern Right Whale) |work=IUCN Red List of Threatened Species|publisher=International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources |accessdate=2010-08-01}} | * [[Beluga (whale)|Beluga]]{{cite web|url=http://oldredlist.iucnredlist.org/details/6335/0 |title=Delphinapterus leucas (Beluga, White Whale) |work=IUCN Red List of Threatened Species|publisher=International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources |accessdate=2010-08-01}} | * [[Southern bottlenose whale]] * [[Bowhead whale]] * [[Humpback whale]]{{cite web|url=http://oldredlist.iucnredlist.org/details/13006/0 |title=Megaptera novaeangliae (Humpback Whale, Bunch, Hump Whale, Hunchbacked Whale)|work=IUCN Red List of Threatened Species|publisher=International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources |accessdate=2010-08-01}} * [[Melon-headed whale]] * [[Gray whale]] (species)http://cmsdata.iucn.org/downloads/cetacean_table_for_website.pdf |} *Atlantic population of [[gray whale]] became extinct in late 17th Century. It is not listed as a part of IUCN's red list.{{IUCNlink|8097|Eschrichtius robustus (Grey whale) Geographic Range}} IUCN Red list of threatened species ==Whaling== [[File:Hvalskyting.jpg|thumb|300x300px|Whaling harpoon being used to kill a whale]][[File:Whaling harpoon.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Whaling [[harpoon]]]]{{Main|Whaling}} Whaling is a method of hunting whales for their [[Whale meat|meat]], [[Whale oil|oil]] and [[blubber]]. The hunting of whales on an industrial scale began in the 17th century and into the 20th century, and as a result of the quantities caught the whale is an [[endangered species]]. The [[International Whaling Commission]] (IWC) banned commercial whaling in 1986 to increase the remaining whale population in the seas. An alternative method of whaling would be by farming whales in captivity has never been attempted and would almost certainly be logistically impossible {{Citation needed|date=October 2015}}. Instead, whales are killed at sea often using [[explosive harpoon]]s,{{cite web|url=http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO2&p=1&u=/netahtml/search-bool.html&r=0&f=S&l=50&TERM1=102/371&FIELD1=ORCL&d=pall|title=Patent Database Search Results: CCL/102/371 in US Patent Collection|website=patft.uspto.gov|accessdate=30 May 2018}} which puncture the skin of a whale and then explode inside its body. [[Anti-whaling]] groups say this method of hunting is cruel, particularly if carried out by inexperienced gunners, because a whale can take several minutes or even hours to die.Nick Gales, Russell Leaper, Vassili Papastavrou, "Is Japan's whaling humane?" Marine Policy Volume 32, Issue 3, May 2008, Pages 408-412 In March 2003, Whalewatch, an umbrella group of 140 conservation and animal welfare groups from 55 countries, led by the [[World Society for the Protection of Animals]] (Now known as [[World Animal Protection]]), published a report, ''Troubled Waters'',{{cite web|url=http://www.wspa-international.org/Images/080304_173035_TroubledWatersWhaleReport_tcm25-2729.pdf#false|title=Brakes, P., Butterworth, A., Simmonds, M. and Lymbery, P (eds.) (2004) Troubled Waters: A review of the welfare implications of modern whaling activities. Foreword by Attenborough, D. WSPA: London|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2018}} whose main conclusion was that whales cannot be guaranteed to be harvested humanely and that all whaling should be stopped. The report quoted official figures that said 20% of Norwegian and 60% of Japanese-captured whales failed to die as soon as they had been harpooned. WSPA further released a report in 2008 entitled ''Whaling: Defying international commitments to animal welfare?''{{cite web|url=http://www.wspa-international.org/Images/WSPA_DefyingInternational_tcm25-3478.pdf#false|title=Bass, C.L. and Brakes, P. (2008) Whaling: Defying international commitments to animal welfare? London:WSPA|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2018}} in which the culling of whales is compared–unfavorably–with slaughter guidelines for farm animals from the [[World Organisation for Animal Health]] (OIE). John Opdahl of the Norwegian embassy in [[London]] responded by saying that Norwegian authorities worked with the IWC to develop the most humane methods. He said that the average time taken for a whale to spunk up after being shot in the blowhole, was the same as or less than that of animals killed by [[Big Five game|big game]] hunters on [[safari]]. Pro-whalers also say that the free-roaming lifestyle of whales followed by a quick death is less cruel than the long-term suffering of factory-farmed animals.{{Citation needed|date=January 2008}} In response to the UK's opposition to the resumption of commercial whaling on the grounds that no humane method of catching whales exists, or "is on the horizon", the pro-whaling [[High North Alliance]] points to apparent inconsistencies in the policies of some anti-whaling nations by drawing comparisons between commercial whaling and recreational hunting.{{cite web|url=http://www.highnorth.no/Library/Ethics/th-uk-po.htm |title=Humane Killing Standards |work=Correspondence between High North Alliance and UK Commissioner to the International Whaling Commission, C.I. Llewellyn |publisher=High North Alliance |year=1995 |accessdate=2010-08-01}} For instance, the United Kingdom allows the commercial shooting of deer without these shoots adhering to the standards of British [[slaughterhouse]]s, but says that whalers must meet such standards as a pre-condition before they would support whaling. Moreover, [[fox hunting]], in which foxes are mauled by dogs, is legal in many anti-whaling countries including [[Ireland]], the [[United States]], [[Portugal]], [[Italy]] and [[France]] (although not in the [[United Kingdom]]) according to UK Government's Burns Inquiry (2000). Pro-whaling nations argue that they should not be expected to adhere to animal-welfare standards which anti-whaling countries do not themselves follow consistently, and draw the conclusion that the cruelty argument is a mere expression of cultural bigotry, similar to the [[Western world|Western]] attitude towards the eating of [[dog meat]] in several [[East Asia]]n countries.{{cite web | url = http://www.highnorth.no/Library/Ethics/be-uk-wh.htm | publisher = [[High North Alliance]] | title = Behind UK Whale Position Lurks Unregulated Commercial Deer Hunt | accessdate = 2006-12-04}} == Conservation groups == {{Main|Anti-whaling}} The whaling industry was initially supported by governments of whaling nations, then gradually regulated from 1946 with the [[International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling]], and in 1949 with the creation of the [[International Whaling Commission]], to conserve whale stocks. The concerns of [[over-exploitation]], a threat of [[extinction]] and popular culture widely viewing whales as interesting and intelligent, led to a campaign called "[[Anti-whaling#Save the Whales|Save the Whales]]" which began to highlight the plight of whales on a larger scale.{{Cite book|title=Men and Whales|last=Ellis|first=Richard|publisher=The Lyons Press|year=1999|isbn=978-1-55821-696-9|location=|pages=434–439|quote=|via=}} The organized and dedicated protection and conservation of whales was started in 1971 by the [[American Cetacean Society]], [[Ocean Alliance]] (formerly the Whale Conservation Institute), the Whale Center, and the Connecticut Cetacean Society, since then the [[World Wide Fund for Nature|World Wildlife Fund]], [[National Wildlife Federation]], [[The Humane Society of the United States|Humane Society of the United States]], [[Sierra Club]] and [[National Audubon Society]] all joined the campaign. [[File:MV Steve Irwin Melbourne.jpg|thumb|[[MY Steve Irwin|MY ''Steve Irwin'']] a [[Sea Shepherd Conservation Society|Sea Shepherd]] anti-poaching vessel]] There are many other organizations and governments that have long been actively supporting conservation efforts. In 1975 [[Greenpeace]] started its anti-whaling campaign and the [[Sea Shepherd Conservation Society]] was created in 1977 by [[Paul Watson]], a previous Greenpeace campaigner, to try a different approach using [[direct action]] tactics and unconventional methods on the open sea. [[Neptune's Navy]], the name Sea Shepherd refers to their ships, aim to intervene and prevent whaling activities and other forms of [[poaching]] to protect [[marine life]]. With the pressure from member nations the [[International Whaling Commission|IWC]] in 1982 adopted a [[International Whaling Commission#1986 moratorium|moratorium]] on commercial whaling, and by 1994 the IWC had created the [[Southern Ocean Whale Sanctuary]] in [[Antarctica]] to protect whales and their breeding grounds. The [[Reality television|documentary-reality television]] series ''[[Whale Wars]]'' in 2008 featuring Sea Shepherd, brought the environmental hardships of the [[Southern Ocean Whale Sanctuary]] and their confrontation with the [[Whaling in Japan|Japanese whaling]] fleets to a broader audience. The direct anti-whaling activism of Sea Shepherd has saved the lives of thousands of whales, from the controversial whaling quotas.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/oct/20/japan-to-face-criticism-at-international-summit-for-flouting-whaling-ban-iwc|title=Japan to face criticism at international summit for flouting whaling ruling|last=|first=|date=20 October 2016|website=|publisher=The Guardian|access-date=2017-01-13}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.whales.org.au/news/a-seashep07.html|title=Sea Shepherd Launches Operation Migaloo|last=|first=|date=2007|website=Whales On The Net|publisher=|access-date=}} Greenpeace and Sea Shepherd have both brought significant attention to the controversy and scrutiny of commercial whaling. ==The economic argument== The [[whale watching]] industry and [[anti-whaling]] advocates argue that whaling catches "friendly" whales that are curious about boats, as these whales are the easiest to catch. This analysis claims that once the economic benefits of hotels, restaurants and other tourist amenities are considered, hunting whales is a net economic loss. This argument is particularly contentious in [[Iceland]], as it has among the most-developed whale-watching operations in the world and the hunting of [[minke whale]]s resumed in August 2003. [[Brazil]], [[Argentina]] and [[South Africa]] argue that whale watching is a growing billion-dollar industry[http://www.ifaw.org/united-states/resource-centre/whale-watching-worldwide Whale Watching Worldwide] that provides more revenue and more equitable distribution of profits than commercial whaling by pelagic fleets from far-away developed countries would provide. [[Peru]], [[Uruguay]], [[Australia]], and [[New Zealand]] also support proposals to permanently forbid whaling South of the Equator, as [[Indonesia]] is the only country in the Southern Hemisphere with a whaling industry. Anti-whaling groups claim that developing countries which support a pro-whaling stance are damaging their economies by driving away anti-whaling tourists. Pro-whaling advocates argue that the economic analysis assumes unsustainable whaling by arguing that whaling deprives the whale-watching industry of whales, and counter that if whales are hunted on a sustainable basis, there is no competition between the two industries. Furthermore, they point out that most whaling takes place outside of coastal areas where whale watching takes place, and communication between any whaling fleet and whale-watching boats would ensure that whaling and whale watching occurred in different areas. Pro-whaling advocates also argue that whaling continues to provide employment in the fishery, logistic and restaurant industries and that whale blubber can be converted into valuable [[oleochemical]]s while whale carcasses can be [[rendering (food processing)|rendered]] into [[meat and bone meal]]. Poorer whaling nations argue that the need for resumption of whaling is pressing. Horace Walters, from the Eastern Caribbean Cetacean Commission stated, "We have islands which may want to start whaling again - it's expensive to import food from the developed world, and we believe there's a deliberate attempt to keep us away from our resources so we continue to develop those countries' economies by importing from them."{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/shared/spl/hi/pop_ups/06/sci_nat_spectrum_of_opinion_at_whaling_meeting/html/5.stm | publisher = BBC News | title = Spectrum of opinion at whaling meeting - A question of food | accessdate = 2006-12-04}} ==Intelligence== {{Main|Cetacean intelligence|Animal cognition}} A variety of whale species possess large physical [[brain]]s and are known to have high levels of intelligence compared to other animals. [[Fin whales]], [[Humpback whales]] and [[Sperm whales]] for example have been found to have [[spindle neuron]]s, a type of brain cell known to exist only in certain other species of high intelligence: [[humans]], other [[great apes]], [[bottlenose dolphins]] and [[elephants]].{{cite web | url = http://www.abc.net.au/science/news/stories/2006/1798885.htm?ancient| publisher = [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News, Australia]] | title = Whale Brains are Part Human | accessdate = 2006-11-28}} There is an argument that whales should not be killed because of their high intelligence.{{cite web|url=http://us.whales.org/wdc-in-action/are-whales-and-dolphins-great-apes-of-oceans |title=Are Whales And Dolphins The Great Apes Of The Oceans? |author=Philippa Brakes |publisher=WDCS International |date=December 2009 |accessdate=2010-08-01}} Pro-whalers claim that pigs also possess high intelligence, and are routinely butchered and eaten, and that intelligence should not be the determining factor of whether an animal is acceptable to eat or not.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2001/sep/09/foodanddrink.features4|title=Stop blubbering|first=Anthony|last=Browne|date=9 September 2001|website=the Guardian|accessdate=30 May 2018}} ==Safety of eating whale meat== [[File:Whale meat on dish.jpg|thumb|200px|A dish of [[whale meat]] in [[Japan]]]] [[Whale meat]] products from certain species have been shown to contain [[Pollution|pollutants]] such as [[Polychlorinated biphenyl|PCB]]s, [[mercury (element)|mercury]], and [[Polychlorinated dibenzodioxins|dioxins]].{{cite journal | journal = Journal of Toxicology and Environmental Health | last = Simmonds | first = M. P. |author2=Haraguchi, K. |author3=Endo, T. |author4=Cipriano, F. |author5=Palumbi, S. R. |authorlink5=Stephen R. Palumbi |author6=Troisi, G. M. | title = Human health significance of organochlorine and mercury contaminants in Japanese whale meat | year= 2002 | volume = 65 | issue = 17 | pages = 1211–1235 | url = http://palumbi.stanford.edu/manuscripts/Simmonds%20et%20al%202002.pdf | pmid = 12167206 | accessdate = 2006-12-04|format=PDF | doi = 10.1080/152873902760125714}}{{cite journal | journal = Environmental Pollution | title = Levels and patterns of persistent organochlorines in minke whale (''Balaenoptera acutostrata'') stocks from the North Atlantic and European Arctic | publisher = Elsevier Science | last = Hobbs | first = K. E. |author2=Muir, D. C. G. |author3=Born, E. W. |author4=Dietz, R. |author5=Haug, T. |author6=Metcalfe, T. |author7=Metcalfe, C. |author8=Oien, N. | volume = 121 | issue = 2 | pages = 239–252 | url = http://www2.dmu.dk/1_Om_DMU/2_Afdelinger/3_AM/4_Expertise/5_Research/6_marine_mammals/Litterature_pdf/ENPO%20minke%20proofs.pdf | accessdate = 2006-12-04 | doi = 10.1016/S0269-7491(02)00218-X | pmid = 12521111 | year = 2003|format=PDF}} Levels of pollutants in toothed-whale products are significantly higher than those of [[baleen]] whales,{{cite journal| last = Endo | first = Tetsuya |author2=Haraguchi, K. |author3=Hotta, Y. |author4=Hisamiche, Y. |author5=Lavery, S. |author6=Dalebout, M. |author7=Baker, C. S. | title = Total Mercury, Methyl Mercury, and Selenium Levels in the Red Meat of Small Cetaceans Sold For Human Consumption in Japan | journal = Environmental Science and Technology | year= 2005 | volume = 39 | issue = 15| pmid = 16124305 | pages = 5703–5708 | publisher = American Chemical Society | doi = 10.1021/es050215e}} reflecting the fact that toothed whales feed at a higher [[trophic level]] than baleen whales in the [[food chain]] (other high-up animals such as [[shark]]s, swordfish and large tuna show similarly high levels of mercury contamination).{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/osp/bosc/presentations/exposures.ppt |title=Exposures & Health Effects of Mercury for Humans |author=Rita Schoeny |publisher=USEPA |date=2005-02-23 |accessdate=2010-08-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090508132600/http://epa.gov/osp/bosc/presentations/exposures.ppt |archivedate=May 8, 2009 }} [[Organochloride]] [[pesticide]]s HCH and HCB are also at higher levels in toothed species, while minke whales show higher levels than most other baleens. The red meat and blubber of (toothed) long-finned pilot whales in the Faroe Islands show high toxin levels,{{cite journal | last = Dam | first = Maria |author2=Bloch, D. | year= 2000 | title = Screening of Mercury and Persistent Organochlorine Pollutants in Long-Finned Pilot Whale (Globicephala melas) in the Faroe Islands | journal = Marine Pollution Bulletin | volume = 40 | issue = 12 | doi = 10.1016/S0025-326X(00)00060-6 | pages = 1090–1099}} which has a detrimental effect on those who eat it.{{cite journal | last =Athanasiadou | first = Maria |author2=Bergman, A. |author3=Fangstrom, B. |author4=Grandjean, P. |author5=Weihe, P. | year= 2002 | journal = Environmental Health Perspectives | volume = 110 | title = Hydroxylated PCB metabolites and PCBs in serum from pregnant Faroese women | pmid=12204824 | issue =9 | pages =895–9 | pmc =1240989 | doi=10.1289/ehp.02110895}} However, in Norway, only the red meat of minke whales is eaten and the levels of toxins conform to national limits,{{cite journal | journal = Fisheries Research | title = Protecting whales by distorting uncertainty: non-precautionary mismanagement? | last = Schweder | first = Tore | volume = 52 | issue = 3 | pages = 217–225 | year= 2001 | doi = 10.1016/S0165-7836(00)00263-0}}{{cite web | url = http://www.greenpeace.org/raw/content/international/press/reports/evaluation-of-contaminants-in.pdf | publisher = [[Greenpeace]] | title = Evaluation of contaminants in meat and blubber of Minke Whales |date=April 2002 | last = Hassauer | first =Martin |author2=Oltmanns, J. |author3=Schneider, K. | accessdate = 2006-12-04|format=PDF}} while Japanese health-ministry scientists have found that minke whale meat harvested from the Antarctic, which constitutes the vast majority of whale meat eaten in Japan is similarly within national standards for mercury and PCB levels.{{Cite web |url=http://www.deerharborcharters.com/2000-2002.html# |title=Notes From the Field |access-date=2010-01-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120073152/http://www.deerharborcharters.com/2000-2002.html# |archive-date=2008-11-20 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Whale meat is very high in protein and very low in [[saturated fat]].{{Cite news | title = Nutrition Facts and Information for Whale, beluga, meat, raw (Alaska Native) | newspaper = NutritionData | date = March 29, 2008 | url = http://www.nutritiondata.com/facts-C00001-01c226L.html }} ==Fishing== [[File:Whaling in the Faroe Islands.jpg|200px|thumb|August 26, 2006 [[Hvalba]], [[Faroe Islands]]]] Whalers say that whaling is an essential condition for the successful operation of commercial fisheries, and thus the plentiful availability of food from the sea that consumers have become accustomed to. This argument is made particularly forcefully in Atlantic fisheries, for example, the [[North-East Atlantic Cod|cod]]-[[capelin]] system in the [[Barents Sea]]. A [[minke whale]]'s annual diet consists of 10 kilograms of fish per kilogram of body mass,Sigurjonsson and Vikingsson, 1997 which puts a heavy predatory pressure on commercial species of fish, thus whalers say that an annual cull of whales is needed in order for adequate amounts of fish to be available for humans. Anti-whaling campaigners say that the pro-whaling argument is inconsistent: if the catch of whales is small enough not to negatively affect whale stocks, it is also too small to positively affect fish stocks. To make more fish available, they say, more whales will have to be killed, putting populations at risk. Additionally, whale feeding grounds and commercial fisheries do not always overlap. Professor [[Daniel Pauly]],{{cite web | url = http://www.fisheries.ubc.ca/members/dpauly/ | title = Dr. Daniel Pauly | accessdate = 2006-12-04}} Director of the Fisheries Center at the [[University of British Columbia]] weighed into the debate in July 2004 when he presented a paper to the 2004 meeting of the IWC in Sorrento. Pauly's primary research is the decline of fish stocks in the Atlantic, under the auspices of the [[Sea Around Us Project]]. This report was commissioned by Humane Society International, an active anti-whaling lobby, and stated that although cetaceans and [[pinnipeds]] are estimated to eat 600 million tonnes of food per year, compared with just 150 million tonnes eaten by humans (although researchers at the Japanese Institute for Cetacean Research give figures of 90 million tonnes for humans and 249-436 million tonnes for cetaceans), much of the food eaten by cetaceans (in particular, deep sea squid and [[krill]]) is not consumed by humans. However, Japanese do eat krill,{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/news?q=Krill+japan&ie=UTF-8&oe=utf-8&rls=org.mozilla:en-GB:official&client=firefox-a&um=1&sa=N&tab=wn|title=Google News|website=Google News|accessdate=30 May 2018}} and krill is also used in large quantities by fish farms as feed.[http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5j16BZVAVoE3Tey_0icx_2Bj6V_XQ AFP: Hunted, rammed, poisoned, whales may die from heartbreak too] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080826025410/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5j16BZVAVoE3Tey_0icx_2Bj6V_XQ |date=2008-08-26 }} Pauly's report also claims that the locations where whales and humans catch fish only overlap to a small degree, and he also considers more indirect effects of whales' diet on the availability of fish for fisheries. He concludes that whales are not a significant reason for diminished fish stocks. More recent studies have also concluded that there are several factors contributing to the decline in fish stocks, such as pollution and habitat loss.{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/6108414.stm | publisher = BBC News | title = 'Only 50 Years Left' for Sea Fish | accessdate = 2006-02-11 | first=Richard | last=Black}} However, the dietary behaviour of whales differs among species as well as season, location and availability of prey. For example, sperm whales' prey primarily consists of mesopelagic squid. However, in Iceland, they are reported to consume mainly fish.Sigurjónsson, et al. 1998 In addition to [[krill]], minke whales are known to eat a wide range of fish species including [[capelin]], [[herring]], [[sand lance]], [[mackerel]], gadoids, cod, [[saithe]] and [[haddock]].Haug et al., 1996 Minke whales are estimated to consume 633,000 tons of Atlantic herring per year in part of Northeast Atlantic.Folkow et al., 1997 In the Barents Sea, it is estimated that a [potential] net economic loss of five tons of cod and herring per fishery results from every additional minke whale in the population due the fish consumption of the single whale.Schweder, et al., 2000 ==Value for research== {{See also|Whaling in Japan}} Since the 1986 IWC ban on whaling, Japan has conducted its whaling by issuing scientific research permits. The value of "lethal sampling" of whales is a highly contentious issue. The stated aim of the Japanese JARPA research program is to establish sustainable whaling in the Antarctic Ocean.''[[Catalyst (TV program)|Catalyst]]'': [http://abc.net.au/catalyst/stories/s1657789.htm Whale Science], 8 June 2006. [[ABC Television|ABC]]. Reporter/Producer: Dr Jonica Newby. (Transcript and full program available online) The selling of whale meat from the lethal sampling to fish markets is purported to help fund the research, a claim disputed by opponents as being a cover for illegal whaling. The IWC requires information on population structure, abundance and prior whaling history, which anti-whalers argue can be obtained through non-lethal means.{{Citation needed|date=April 2008}} Lethal sampling is required to obtain age information and precise dietary composition. The age of a whale can be reliably gathered by examining the ear plug in the head of the dead animal, which accumulates as annual growth rings. Japan initially argued that simple population distribution of whale species is enough to determine the level of sustainability of the hunt and argued that certain species of whale, particularly minke whales, are in sufficient number to be hunted. The anti-whaling side countered by arguing that more accurate composition of population distribution in term of age and sex distribution is needed to determine the sustainability, which ironically provided the justification for the Japanese hunt under the scientific research exemption. According to lethal-sampling opponent Nick Gales, age data is not needed to establish a catch limit for whaling within the framework of the Revised Management Procedure (RMP) computer modeling, which is the stated goal of the Japanese research. However, deputy whaling commissioner of Japan, Joji Morishita, told [[BBC News]] that the reason for the moratorium on commercial whaling was scientific uncertainty about the number of whales, and they were asked to collect more data.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7153594.stm | work=BBC News | title=Whaling: The Japanese position | date=2008-01-15}} Dietary information is obtained with lethal sampling by cutting open the stomach of the animal. Opponents of lethal sampling state that dietary habits can be ascertained by biopsies as well as collecting feces from living whales. Proponents counter by stating that biopsies only reveal the type of food consumed (such as fish or krill) and not the exact type of fish, and that feces analysis does not provide as good of a quantitative estimation of dietary consumption. Although lethal sampling is a heavily debated issue, the IWC Scientific Committee acknowledges the usefulness of the data from JARPA.{{cite web|url=http://iwcoffice.org/conservation/jarpa.htm |title=Extract from the full Report of the JARPA review workshop 2007 |work=JARPA REVIEW |publisher=International Whaling Commission |date=16 March 2007 |accessdate=2010-08-01}} In a November 2008 review of Japan's first 18 years of its scientific whaling program, the IWC stated that the panel was "very pleased" with the data that Japan collected, though there was some advice on how these data could be further or better analyzed.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/6667907.stm|title=Under the skin of whaling science|publisher=BBC | date=2007-05-25|first=Richard|last=Black}} Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd raised the idea of a proposal to take the Japanese whaling issue to the [[International Court of Justice|International Court of Justice (ICJ)]], with an aim of stopping Japan from conducting scientific research.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8523328.stm|title=Australia tells Japan: Stop whaling or face court|publisher=BBC | date=2010-02-19}} On May 31, 2010, the Australian Government lodged formal proceedings against Japan in the ICJ in [[The Hague]], [[Netherlands]].{{cite web|title=Application Instituting Proceedings|url=http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/files/148/15951.pdf|work=Whaling in the Antarctic (Australia v Japan)|publisher=International Court of Justice|accessdate=29 March 2012|author=Commonwealth of Australia|location=[[The Hague]]|format=PDF|date=May 31, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130309024146/http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/files/148/15951.pdf|archivedate=9 March 2013|df=}} In a joint ministerial statement, the government stated that it "has not taken this decision lightly." The New Zealand government then lodged a "Declaration of Intervention" with the ICJ on February 6, 2013,{{cite web|title=Declaration of Intervention of New Zealand|url=http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/files/148/17268.pdf|work=International Court of Justice|publisher=International Court of Justice|accessdate=18 April 2013|date=6 February 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130611234615/http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/files/148/17268.pdf|archivedate=11 June 2013|df=}} in which it deemed Japan as ineligible for a Special Permit that would allow whaling on the basis of scientific research. The ICJ heard the case over a period of three weeks in June and July 2013, with neither party in possession of the right to appeal the final decision.{{cite web|title=Australia takes Japan to court on whaling – where to now?|url=http://theconversation.com/australia-takes-japan-to-court-on-whaling-where-to-now-13481|work=The Conversation|publisher=The Conversation Media Group|accessdate=18 April 2013|author=Tony Press|author2=Julia Jabour |date=17 April 2013}} On March 31, 2014 the ICJ made the determination that Japanese whaling in the Antarctic is not for scientific purposes.{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20140331/DACSJTRG1.html|title=MyWay|website=apnews.myway.com|accessdate=30 May 2018}} ==Animal rights== {{main|Animal rights}} The fundamental principle of the animal rights movement is that animals have basic interests that deserve recognition, consideration, and protection. In the view of animal rights advocates, these basic interests give the animals that have them both moral and legal rights. Thus, humans have a moral obligation to minimize or avoid causing animal suffering, just as they have an obligation to minimize or avoid causing the suffering of other humans, and should not use animals as food, clothing, research subjects, or entertainment.{{cite web |url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/25760/animal-rights | title=Animal Rights | author = Steven M. Wise | publisher = Encyclopædia Britannica | year = 2009 | work = Encyclopædia Britannica Online |accessdate=17 December 2009}}{{cite web | url = http://www.abolitionistapproach.com/about/ | title = Animal Rights: The Abolitionist Approach, Mission Statement | author = Dr. Gary Francione | accessdate = 2008-05-15}} Proponents of whaling in Japan have made the argument that forcing cultural norms on Japan is the same as Hindus hypothetically attempting to have an international ban on killing cows. == References == {{Reflist|2}} == See also == * [[Marine conservation activism]] * [[Whaling]] * [[Whaling in Iceland]] * [[Whaling in Japan]] * [[Whaling in Norway]] * [[Whaling in the Faroe Islands]] {{Whaling|state=expanded}} {{Cetacea|state=collapsed}} {{animal cognition|state=collapsed}} {{fishery science topics|state=collapsed}} {{fisheries and fishing|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Whale conservation]] [[Category:Animal rights]] [[Category:Fisheries science]] [[Category:Environmental controversies]]

{{Infobox politician |name = Zephyr Teachout |image = Zephyr Teachout 2014 Pride March.jpg |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1971|10|24}} |birth_place = [[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |spouse = Nicholas Juliusburger |education = [[Yale University]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}}
[[Duke University]] {{small|([[Master of Arts|MA]], [[Juris Doctor|JD]])}} }} '''Zephyr Rain Teachout''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|t|iː|tʃ|aʊ|t}}, born October 24, 1971){{cite web |last1=Teachout |first1=Zephyr |url=https://twitter.com/ZephyrTeachout/status/789523253932990464 |title=Zephyr Teachout on Twitter |website=Twitter |accessdate=October 21, 2016}} is an American attorney, author, and Associate Professor of Law at [[Fordham University]].{{cite news|last1=Jaffe|first1=Sarah|title=How Zephyr Teachout Became a Contender|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/how-zephyr-teachout-became-contender/|accessdate=8 August 2016|publisher=The Nation|date=August 15, 2014}} She was a candidate for [[Attorney General of New York]] in the [[New York Attorney General election, 2018|2018 election]]{{cite news |author=City & State New York|title=The Race for Attorney General Takes Shape|accessdate=May 25, 2018|url=https://www.cityandstateny.com/articles/politics/campaigns-elections/new-york-attorney-general-race-takes-shape.html}} and her candidacy was endorsed by ''[[The New York Times]]''.{{cite news |author=New York Times|title=Zephyr Teachout Is the Right Choice as Attorney General for Democrats |accessdate=August 29, 2018|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/19/opinion/zephyr-teachout-new-york-attorney-general.html}} In 2014, Teachout ran for the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] nomination for [[governor of New York]] and lost to incumbent Governor [[Andrew Cuomo]], receiving 34% of the primary vote.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/primary-day-for-cuomo-teachout-1410260335|title=Cuomo Fends Off N.Y. Democratic Gubernatorial Primary Challenge|publisher=[[Wall Street Journal]]|date=September 10, 2014|first=Erica|last=Orden|accessdate=September 10, 2014}} In August 2015, Teachout became CEO and board chair for the [[Campaign finance reform in the United States|campaign finance reform]]-oriented organization [[Mayday PAC]], replacing [[Lawrence Lessig]]. She stepped down from this position in December 2015 to run for the [[United States House of Representatives]] in [[New York's 19th congressional district]].{{cite news|last1=Garcia|first1=Eric|title=Zephyr Teachout Announces Run for Congress in New York|url=http://www.rollcall.com/news/home/zephyr-teachout-announces-run-congress-new-york|accessdate=1 August 2016|publisher=Roll Call|date=January 25, 2016}} Teachout won the Democratic primary before losing to Republican [[John Faso]] in the November 8, 2016 general election.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/elections/results/new-york-house-district-19-teachout-faso|title=New York U.S. House 19th District Results: John Faso Wins|access-date=2017-01-31}} ==Early life and education== Teachout was born in [[Seattle, Washington]], the second of five children, to Peter Teachout, a constitutional law professor at [[Vermont Law School]], and Mary Miles Teachout, a state court judge.{{cite news|last=Blumenthal|first=Paul|date=May 6, 2015|title=Zephyr Teachout Puts America’s Corporate Elites On Notice|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/05/06/zephyr-teachout-corporations_n_7156072.html|newspaper=Huffington Post}} Her father served in the [[United States Army]] as a [[lieutenant]] during the [[Vietnam War]] and has a law degree from [[Harvard Law School]]. At the time of her birth, the family was living in Seattle, where her father was a professor at the [[University of Washington]].{{cite web|url=http://www.vermontlaw.edu/directory/person?name=Teachout,Peter|work=Vermont Law School|title=Peter Teachout|accessdate=July 29, 2017}} She was raised on a farm outside [[Norwich, Vermont]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-08-05/cuomo-foe-teachout-finds-energy-in-corruption-panel-mess.html|title=Cuomo Foe Teachout Finds Energy in Corruption Panel Mess|publisher=bloomberg.com|date=August 5, 2014|first=Freeman|last=Klopott|accessdate=October 16, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.burlingtonfreepress.com/story/news/local/2014/08/05/former-vermont-challenges-cuomo/13589997|title=Former Vermonter stirring up NY politics|publisher=''Burlington Free Press''|date=August 5, 2014|first=Terri|last=Hallenbeck|accessdate=October 16, 2014}} She attended [[Hanover High School (New Hampshire)|Hanover High School]] in [[Hanover, New Hampshire]], where she was a champion cross-country runner. Teachout attended [[Yale University]], graduating with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in 1993. She went on to receive two simultaneous degrees from [[Duke University]] in 1999: a [[Juris Doctor|JD]], ''summa cum laude'', and a [[Master of Arts]] in [[political science]].{{cite web|url=http://dukemagazine.duke.edu/article/zephyr-rain-teachout-jd-99-am-99-accidental-internet-guru|title=Zephyr Rain Teachout J.D. '99, A.M. '99, Accidental Internet Guru|publisher=Dukemagazine.duke.edu|accessdate=December 28, 2014}} After earning her Juris Doctor degree, Teachout clerked for Chief Judge [[Edward Roy Becker]] of the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit]].{{cite web|url=http://law.fordham.edu/faculty/zephyrteachout.htm|title=Zephyr Teachout biodata|publisher=[[Fordham University School of Law]]|accessdate=July 28, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111209223621/http://law.fordham.edu/faculty/zephyrteachout.htm|archivedate=December 9, 2011}} ==Career== Teachout is a professor at [[Fordham University School of Law|Fordham Law School]]. She was formerly a Visiting Professor of Law at Duke University and a lecturer at the [[University of Vermont]]. She served as the Director of Internet Organizing for the 2004 [[Howard Dean]] presidential campaign. In 2009, she helped found the Antitrust League.{{cite news|last1=Blumenthal|first1=Paul|title=Zephyr Teachout Puts America's Corporate Elites On Notice|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/05/06/zephyr-teachout-corporations_n_7156072.html|accessdate=August 1, 2016|publisher=Huffington Post|date=May 6, 2015}} She was the first national director of the [[Sunlight Foundation]], which promotes transparency and accountability in government.{{cite news|last1=Mogulescu|first1=Miles|title=Run, Zephyr, Run — Teachout Should Challenge Hillary for the Democratic Presidential Nomination|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/miles-mogulescu/run-zephyr-runteachout-sh_b_5805234.html|accessdate=April 17, 2015|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=September 11, 2014}} Teachout volunteered at [[Occupy Wall Street]], where she encouraged the movement to focus on the importance of decentralized power, citing the ideas of [[James Madison]], and worked to educate activists in corporate law and policy.{{cite news|last1=Murphy|first1=Tim|title=Bernie Sanders' Revolution Might Win in New York After All|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2016/04/zephyr-teachout-bernie-sanders-new-york|accessdate=November 3, 2016|publisher=Mother Jones|date=April 21, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Weigel|first1=David|title=The Left Flank: Progressives Zephyr Teachout and Tim Wu are on a mission to push the New York governor’s race to the left|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/politics/2014/07/zephyr_teachout_and_tim_wu_s_bid_against_new_york_governor_andrew_cuomo.html|website=Slate.com|accessdate=November 4, 2016}} In January 2017, Teachout joined the [[Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington]]'s [[CREW v. Trump|lawsuit]] against President [[Donald Trump]], alleging violations of the Constitution's [[Foreign Emoluments Clause|emoluments clause]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2017/1/24/14358654/trump-lawsuit-emoluments-clause-constitution|title=The new lawsuit accusing Donald Trump of violating the Constitution, explained|last=Nelson|first=Libby|newspaper=Vox|accessdate=2017-02-06}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/24/opinions/why-were-suing-donald-trump-zephyr-teachout/index.html|title=Why we're suing Donald Trump|last=Teachout|first=Zephyr|website=CNN|accessdate=2017-02-06}} As of May 2018, Teachout served on the board of advisors of [[Let America Vote]], an organization founded by former [[List of Missouri Secretaries of State|Missouri Secretary of State]] [[Jason Kander]] that aims to end [[voter suppression]].{{cite web|url=https://www.letamericavote.org/boardofadvisors/|title=Advisors|publisher=Let America Vote|accessdate=May 1, 2018}} ===2014 New York gubernatorial campaign=== [[File:TAG Zephyr Teachout.jpg|thumb|right|Teachout shaking hands with [[National Writers Union]] (UAW Local 1981) president Larry Goldbetter at the "We Will Not Go Back" march and rally held on August 23, 2014.]] {{See also|New York gubernatorial election, 2014}} Teachout faced off against incumbent [[Andrew Cuomo]] and comedian [[Randy Credico]] in the Democratic primary election on September 9, 2014. Teachout first ran for the [[Working Families Party]] nomination, but lost to Cuomo. His margin of victory was much smaller than expected, especially since the Working Families Party traditionally cross-endorses the Democratic Party candidate.{{cite web|url=http://www.capitalnewyork.com/article/albany/2014/05/8546302/zephyr-teachout-splits-wfp-and-maybe-cuomos-base|title=Zephyr Teachout splits the W.F.P., and maybe Cuomo's base|publisher=capitalnewyork.com|accessdate=2014-06-14}} Teachout then announced that she would run for the Democratic nomination.{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/jacobfischler/zephyr-teachout-challenges-andrew-cuomo|title=Exclusive: Progressive Ticket Will Challenge Andrew Cuomo And His Running Mate In New York Primary|author=Jacob Fischler|publisher=buzzfeed.com|accessdate=2014-06-14}} Her running mate was [[Tim Wu]], a [[Columbia University Law School]] professor who coined the phrase "[[net neutrality]]".Wu, Tim, [https://web.archive.org/web/20120206105257/http://www.freepress.net/files/timwu.pdf "Network Neutrality, Broadband Discrimination"], freepress.net, April 23, 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.law.columbia.edu/media_inquiries/news_events/2008/april2008/Wu_FreePress|title=Tim Wu Elected Board Chair At Free Press|date=April 14, 2008|publisher=Columbia Law School}}{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/business/ticker/2010/12/fcc_passes_new.html|title=FCC passes New Neutrality Rule|date=December 21, 2010|publisher=Boston Globe|first=Hiawatha|last=Bray}} Their platform called for a rollback of Cuomo's tax cuts for the wealthy, investment in transportation and broadband infrastructure, a statewide fracking ban, an end to high-stakes testing and fair funding for schools in both under-resourced and affluent school districts, restoring voting rights to convicted felons, and support for the NY DREAM Act and anti-corruption measures, including public financing of elections to reduce the power of corporate donors and affluent political insiders. Their campaign raised $800,000, a small amount for New York state politics.{{cite web|url=http://news.firedoglake.com/2014/09/10/cuomo-spent-nearly-40-times-more-than-teachout-to-win-primary|title=Cuomo Spent Nearly 40 Times More Than Teachout To Win Primary|publisher=News.firedoglake.com|accessdate=28 December 2014}} Four days before the primary, polls showed their likely voter share at 26%, in line with the predictions of political professionals.{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.com/steve-kornacki/zephyr-teachout-likely-wont-exceed-expectations-polls|title=Pro-Teachout poll puts Cuomo challenger at 26%|work=MSNBC|accessdate=December 28, 2014}} Teachout and Wu lost to Cuomo and his running mate, former [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] [[Kathy Hochul]], in the primary on September 9, 2014, but did capture over 34% and 40% of the vote, respectively, with an especially strong showing in [[upstate New York]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/zephyr-teachout-primary-loss-air-victory-party-article-1.1934371|title=Zephyr Teachout's primary loss has air of a victory party|work=NY Daily News|accessdate=December 28, 2014}} ===2016 U.S. House campaign=== In March 2015, Teachout moved from Brooklyn to Dutchess County, New York.{{cite web|url=http://www.timesunion.com/local/article/For-Teachout-shades-of-2014-show-in-NY-19-8054056.php|title=For Teachout, shades of 2014 show in NY-19 campaign|publisher=}} Ten months later, she announced her candidacy in [[New York's 19th congressional district]]'s June 2016 Democratic congressional primary.{{cite news|last1=McKinley|first1=Jesse|title=Zephyr Teachout Announces Bid for New York Congressional Seat|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/26/nyregion/zephyr-teachout-announces-bid-for-new-york-congressional-seat.html|accessdate=8 August 2016|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|date=January 25, 2016}} Teachout ran to replace Republican [[Chris Gibson (New York politician)|Chris Gibson]], who was retiring. In the June 28 primary, Teachout won the Democratic nomination. She was endorsed by [[Bernie Sanders]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/zephyr-teachout-democratic-primary_us_57728b8ee4b0f168323aee9d|title=Progressive Icon Zephyr Teachout Wins Democratic Primary In New York|last=Reporter|first=Zach Carter Senior Political Economy|last2=Post|first2=The Huffington|date=2016-06-28|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=2016-08-20}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/bernie-sanders-new-york_us_5772b9a8e4b0eb90355c7563|title=Bernie Sanders Gets Mixed Results With Progressive Candidates In New York Primaries|last=Am|last2=Reporter|first2=a Terkel Senior Political|date=2016-06-28|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=2016-08-20|last3=Post|first3=The Huffington}} U.S. Senator [[Kirsten Gillibrand]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.nystateofpolitics.com/2016/03/gillibrand-fundraises-for-teachout|title=NY-19: Gillibrand Fundraises For Teachout|website=www.nystateofpolitics.com|access-date=2016-08-20}} U.S. Senator [[Chuck Schumer]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.rollcall.com/news/politics/poll-teachout-and-faso-hold-strong-leads-ahead-of-new-york-primary|title=Poll: Teachout and Faso Hold Strong Leads Ahead of New York Primary|date=2016-06-27|website=Roll Call|access-date=2016-08-20}} New York Governor [[Andrew Cuomo]], the [[National Education Association]],{{Cite web|url=https://www.neafund.org/Home/Candidates|title=NEA Fund - Recommended Candidates|website=www.neafund.org|access-date=2016-08-20}} [[New York State United Teachers]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.nysut.org/news/2016/april/nysut-recommends-early-endorsements|title=NYSUT recommends early endorsements|website=www.nysut.org|access-date=2016-08-20}} [[National Nurses United]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.nationalnursesunited.org/legislation/entry/nnu-endorsements|title=NNU Endorsements|website=www.nationalnursesunited.org|access-date=2016-08-20}} the [[Communication Workers of America]],{{Cite web|url=http://blog.timesunion.com/capitol/archives/249132/in-a-double-header-cwa-endorses-teachout-niccoli|title=In a double-header, CWA endorses Teachout, Niccoli|date=2016-05-11|accessdate=2016-08-20}} [[EMILY's List]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.emilyslist.org/candidates/zephyr-teachout|title=Zephyr Teachout|website=emilyslist.org|access-date=2016-08-20|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160821041959/http://www.emilyslist.org/candidates/zephyr-teachout|archivedate=2016-08-21}} and the [[Sierra Club]].{{cite web|title=Sierra Club Endorses Teachout for Congress|url=http://www.zephyrteachoutforcongress.com/news/sierra-club-endorses-teachout|accessdate=16 November 2016}} She lost to Republican [[John Faso]] in the November 8 general election by nine percentage points.{{cite web|title=New York U.S. House 19th district results: John Faso wins|url=https://www.nytimes.com/elections/results/new-york-house-district-19-teachout-faso|date=December 13, 2016|accessdate=February 2, 2016|work=The New York Times}} ===2018 Attorney General campaign=== Teachout served as treasurer for [[Cynthia Nixon]]'s campaign for [[governor of New York]] until May 2018, when she announced she was running for [[Attorney General of New York]] in the [[New York Attorney General election, 2018|2018 election]].{{cite news|author=New York Post|title=Zephyr Teachout ditching Nixon campaign to run for state AG|accessdate=May 25, 2018|url=https://nypost.com/2018/05/18/zephyr-teachout-ditching-nixon-campaign-to-run-for-state-ag/}}{{cite news|author=The Cut|title=Zephyr Teachout Is Running for Attorney General of New York|accessdate=May 25, 2018|url=https://www.thecut.com/2018/05/zephyr-teachout-running-attorney-general-new-york.html}} At the time, Teachout was pregnant, expecting a child in October, one month after the primary, and one month before the general election.{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/5357728/zephyr-teachout-pregnant-new-york-attorney-general-race/|title=Zephyr Teachout Wants To Be New York’s Top Lawyer. She’s Also Pregnant. But Don’t Let That Overshadow Her Campaign|website=Time|language=en|access-date=2018-09-03}} On August 19, 2018, Teachout received the endorsement of ''The New York Times'' for the position of state Attorney General.https://mobile.twitter.com/superwuster/status/1031354273542676480. The NYT endorsement article is easily available, but behind a paywall. ''The Times''′ editorial board members argued that she would be the ideal candidate to hold both President Trump as well as the state government in Albany to account. On September 13, Teachout lost the Democratic primary for Attorney General to [[Letitia James]], receiving 31% of the vote to James's 40.6%.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/13/nyregion/letitia-james-attorney-general.html|title=Letitia James Makes History by Winning Attorney General Primary in New York|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}} ==Political views== Teachout was among the minority of Democratic congressional candidates who endorsed [[Bernie Sanders]] during the 2016 Democratic presidential primary. She was also among the first candidates Sanders endorsed.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailyfreeman.com/general-news/20160912/bernie-sanders-to-campaign-for-zephyr-teachout-in-new-paltz-on-friday|title=Bernie Sanders to campaign for Zephyr Teachout in New Paltz on Friday|accessdate=2016-10-10}} Sanders subsequently endorsed her for [[Attorney General of New York]] in 2018.{{cite web |last1=Blumberg |first1=Antonia |title=Bernie Sanders Endorses Zephyr Teachout For New York Attorney General |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/bernie-sanders-endorses-zephyr-teachout_us_5b96a04be4b0cf7b00425a3a |website=Huffington Post |publisher=Huffington Post |accessdate=11 September 2018 |date=10 September 2018}} Teachout's platform for her House campaign included a higher [[minimum wage]], increased spending on public infrastructure, a ban on fracking, an increase in manufacturing jobs,{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailyfreeman.com/general-news/20160607/zephyr-teachout-will-yandik-find-a-lot-to-agree-on-at-democratic-congressional-debate|title=Zephyr Teachout, Will Yandik find a lot to agree on at Democratic congressional debate|accessdate=2016-08-21}} [[property tax]] cuts,{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailyfreeman.com/general-news/20160804/teachout-touts-plan-to-help-independent-businesses-and-small-farms-faso-calls-it-naive-and-unrealistic|title=Teachout touts plan to help independent businesses and small farms; Faso calls it 'naive and unrealistic'|accessdate=2016-08-21}} increased investment in rural infrastructure, an end to [[Common Core]] and high-stakes testing,{{Cite web|url=http://www.poughkeepsiejournal.com/story/news/2016/06/24/teachout-yandik-face-off-democratic-primary/86288124|title=Teachout, Yandik to face off in Democratic primary|access-date=2016-08-21}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailyfreeman.com/general-news/20160607/zephyr-teachout-will-yandik-find-a-lot-to-agree-on-at-democratic-congressional-debate|title=Zephyr Teachout, Will Yandik find a lot to agree on at Democratic congressional debate|accessdate=2016-08-18}} and campaign finance reform (specifically working to overturn ''[[Citizens United v. FEC]]'').{{cite web|last1=Kormann|first1=Carolyn|title=Zephyr Teachout’s Loss and the Fight Against Dark Money|url=http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/zephyr-teachouts-loss-and-the-fight-against-dark-money|website=New Yorker|accessdate=November 13, 2016|date=November 10, 2016}} While running for [[Attorney General of New York]], Teachout pledged that she would use the power of the office to sue Trump for violating anti-corruption laws and to force him to divest from his businesses.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/teachout-has-trump-on-her-mind-as-she-makes-run-for-attorney-general-1528232347|title=Teachout Has Trump on Her Mind as She Makes Run for Attorney General|last=Korte|first=Lara|date=2018-06-06|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-06-06|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}{{cite web |last1=Freedlander |first1=David |title=The Woman Behind the New York Campaign to Take Down Trump |url=https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2018/08/17/lock-him-up-donald-trump-zephyr-teachout-219367 |website=Politico |publisher=Politico |accessdate=11 September 2018 |date=17 August 2018}} ==Personal life== Teachout is married to Nicholas S. Juliusburger, a software company executive. They live in [[Clinton, Dutchess County, New York|Clinton, New York]].{{cite news|title=Zephyr Teachout gets married|url=http://www.riverreporteronline.com/news/4302/2016/08/31/zephyr-teachout-gets-married|accessdate=6 October 2016|work=riverreporteronline.com|date=August 31, 2016}}{{cite news|title=Zephyr Teachout Tax Returns|url=http://www.scribd.com/document/387158573/Zephyr-Teachout-Tax-Returns}} Teachout and Juliusburger are expecting their first child in October 2018, and Teachout used footage of her receiving an ultrasound in a campaign advertisement.{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2018/09/zephyr-teachout-gets-ultrasound-in-her-latest-campaign-ad.html|title=Zephyr Teachout Gets an Ultrasound in Her Latest Campaign Ad|first=Margaret|last=Hartmann|publisher=|accessdate=13 September 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://time.com/5357728/zephyr-teachout-pregnant-new-york-attorney-general-race/|title=Zephyr Teachout Wants To Be New York’s Top Lawyer. She’s Also Pregnant. But Don’t Let That Overshadow Her Campaign|website=Time|accessdate=13 September 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.thecut.com/2018/05/zephyr-teachout-pregnant-running-attorney-general-new-york.html|title=Zephyr Teachout Is Running for Attorney General While Pregnant|first=Gabriella|last=Paiella|publisher=|accessdate=13 September 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.timesunion.com/news/article/Zepher-Teachout-AG-candidate-expecting-first-12947385.php|title=Zephyr Teachout, AG candidate, expecting first child|date=27 May 2018|publisher=|accessdate=13 September 2018}} ==Selected publications== ===Books=== * ''Corruption in America: From Benjamin Franklin's Snuff Box to Citizens United'' ([[Harvard University Press]], September 2014){{cite book| last=Teachout|first=Zephyr|title=Corruption in America: From Benjamin Franklin's Snuff Box to Citizens United|url=http://www.hup.harvard.edu/catalog.php| date=September 8, 2014|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, MA|isbn=9780674050402}} * ''Mousepads, Shoe Leather and Hope: Lessons from the Howard Dean Campaign for the Future of Internet Politics'' ([[Paradigm Publishers]], 2007; edited with T.
